comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Dunmore Castle ~ Dunmore The first castle was built here by de Bermingham about 1225, but it was burned by the sons of the kings of Connacht in 1249, by Fichra O'Flynn in 1284 and by Rory O'Connor in 1315. The present castle was probably built after the last burning. It is a massive rectangular tower of four storeys situated on a motte with the remains of a fortifying wall around it. Dunmore Castle Dunmore County Galway The tower is bare inside, and the mullioned windows on the top floor suggest that it was partially rebuilt and used in the late 16th or early 17th century. Although taken by Sir Henry Sidney, it remained in de Bermingham hands until the Cromwellian plantations, and was inhabited until the last century. dunmore.galway-ireland.ie/dunmore-castle.htm

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: St. Patrick is said to have built a monastery in Dunmore, upon the site of which a friary for Hermits of St. Augustine was afterwards founded by Walter de Birmingham, Lord Athenry, in 1425. After the Reformation part of the friary was converted into a parish church of the establishment, the rest being levelled, now forms the market place. www.tuam-guide.com/dunmore.htm

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: The first recorded Bermingham in Ireland, Robert de Bermingham (son of William) accompanied Richard de Clare or 'Strongbow' in Henry II's conquest of Ireland in 1172. ....... The Pierce de Bermingham mentioned above held a castle at Carrick in county Kildare and is noted in history for murdering over twenty of the O' Connors clan at a feast he held there in 1305. For this 'notorious' act he earned the title of the 'Treacherous Baron'. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bermingham_(surname)

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: William Bermingham is the son of Meiler Bermingham and Basile of Worcester. He held the office of Archbishop of Tuam in 1289. His younger Brother Piers Bermingham, became 1st Lord Athenry He married, secondly, Maud of Rokeby, daughter of Richard of Rokeby. He died on 2 April 1307. He was buried at Athenry Priory, Athenry, County Galway, Ireland. thepeerage.com/p4169.htm#i41681

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Meiler Bermingham was born circa 1213.1 He was the son of Piers Bermingham. He married Basile of Worcester, daughter of William of Worcester. He died in 1263 at near Cashel. He was buried at Athenry Priory, Athenry, County Galway, Ireland. He was also known as Maeiler Mor of Athenry. He was also known as Meiler MacPhioris. In 1244 he was granted a market at Athenry. He founded the monastery for Dominicans at Athenry.1 He lived at Athenry, County Galway, Ireland. thepeerage.com/p4167.htm#i41669

comment.author: 99002941@N08
comment._content:
The name 'R. Welch' down in the left corner certainly suggests him... He signed a rather famous photo he made of Harland & Wolff's turning shop in 1897 the same way, so it must be him.

He must have been annoyed by missing the bit at the top, he one spent a half hour making successive exposures of a flower to get just the one he wanted so his perfectionism must have tickled him when he saw this!

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: Robert Bermingham died before 1218. In 1172 he accompanied King Henry II in his invasion of Ireland. Between 1175 and 1179 he was witness to some important Irish charters. thepeerage.com/p4167.htm#i41669

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] You are very welcome - it is fun to find these places from the other side of the world before the Irish Flickroonies - btw, where are they today/yesterday? [http://www.flickr.com/photos/48236157@N02] Short answer "It's complicated!", like most Irish history. Anglo-Normans and Welsh were also involved, and a Fairy (!) according to this -
" ... Tradition has it that Hosty, the son of Membric a distinguished warrior of the Welsh nation, commenced erecting a castle a short distance from where the present castle now stands. But that the Fairy who presides over the place, Mór Ní Mhananain, not wishing that he should erect his fort there, destroyed by night as much as his masons had erected by day. She continued to do so for several nights until Hosty consulted a magician, who told him, not to place his fortress there as Mór Ní Mhananain did not wish it. But she would be willing to allow him to erect it on the site of her own fort, and so delighted to view so lofty a pile towering over the humble mounds of her ancient fortress, suffered no fairy to interrupt the work. This account was handed down to Cormac Dall O Coimín to Donnel Treacy who told it to Fr. Neary in the 1880s. ... "
From - dunmorehistoricalsociety.com/dunmore-castle/ More about the Fairy, history etc - www.aughty.org/pdf/dunmore_galway_neary.pdf
